cisc3120.asteroids

Class Asteroids

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Component
      • java.awt.Canvas
        • cisc3120.asteroids.Game
          • cisc3120.asteroids.Asteroids
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible

     class Asteroids
extends Game
    Class which controls the game logic specific to Asteroids. Because it extends Game, this automatically "redraws" itself every hundredth of a second. Your work is in two main places: (1) the constructor, which should create every object that you need at the beginning of the game (ships, asteroids...), and (2) the paint() method, which should describe how to paint the game each time the screen is refreshed. (Note: each object in the game should know how to "paint itself"--much of the real game logic will be in those paint methods, since that's when objects in the game will "move.")
    Author:
    Scott Dexter

    • Constructor Detail

      • Asteroids

        public Asteroids()
        Populate the game. This 'skeleton' calls the Game constructor to set things up, and also defines a Point at the center of the game. You need to create the objects in the game. Make sure the last thing the constructor does is invoke repaint() .

    • Method Detail

      • paint

        public void paint(java.awt.Graphics brush)
        Paints the game. This 'skeleton' paints the screen black, then gets ready to draw in white. You need to tell it what else to pain.
        Overrides:
        paint in class java.awt.Canvas
        See Also:
        Canvas.paint(java.awt.Graphics)

        Aha: here's where everything gets started: simply by invoking the Asteroids constructor.
